name: 施欣文
objective:
本課程旨在提昇學生撰寫結構完整段落和短文之能力, 並著重如何重寫、摘要、 轉述、 陳述、筆記、編排、起草、修改等相關技巧。

This course will help you organize and present your ideas in clear, fluent, logical paragraphs. Students will learn to analyze their own voice, style, and word choice with the goal of becoming more creative at the same time as they learn to write more clearly. We will workshop papers in small groups and as a class, helping students analyze their own and other students’ writing. Many weeks will also involve a review of important grammatical points.
schedule: Please see hard copy for the week by week assignments. You will write one narrative, one persuasive letter, and one to two literary analyses/argument papers during the course of the semester, in addition to reading and informal writing assignments.
scorePolicy:
ASSIGNMENTS
•	In order to receive credit for this course, you must complete all assignments, drafts, and revisions. 
•	You are expected to make substantial revisions to each draft so that you can think about your issue as deeply and specifically as possible. 
•	All assignments are due in hard copy at the beginning of class. (You will have technology problems. Make sure to print your paper early enough that you will not run into difficulties with non-functioning printers.) For formal papers I take off 5% if you are late to class on a paper due date (10% if you are fifteen or more minutes late), 10% if the paper is turned in within twenty-four hours after the due date (4:00 p.m. on Wednesday) and 20% if the paper is turned in within forty-eight hours of the deadline (4:00 p.m. on Thursday). You will not receive any credit for a paper turned in more than 48 hours late. Late papers should be turned in both by an e-mail Word document (which must open if you wish to receive credit) and in an identical hard copy. (The e-mail lets me know at what time you turned in your paper. However, I only grade hard copies, and you must put the paper in my box as well.) I hope that you will turn in all papers on time [losing 10–20% can be dangerous, especially if the paper is just so-so rather than excellent], but in the event that a paper is late, bring it to my office. If I am not in my office, put the paper my box. Please also immediately send me an e-mail alerting me that you have left a paper for me. If you wish to receive credit for a late paper, it is your responsibility to make sure that the paper gets to me safely. 
•	In addition to the paper assignments, you will have informal writing exercises, grammar homework, quizzes, peer reviews, and presentations. Informal writing assignments, homework, and quizzes are not usually listed on the syllabus. 
•	No credit is given for late homework. If you will be absent, give me the assignment ahead of time.
•	Please bring a notebook with removable pages to every class period. Begin freewrites on a new page. (I sometimes collect them. I sometimes don’t.) 

REVISION AND WORKSHOPS

Be prepared to make multiple copies of drafts for peer review. You may take as many as three drafts home with you to read and comment on. We will then discuss these drafts in a workshop setting.  You will sometimes rate the usefulness of the comments received from other group members. Your ratings and my assessment of their comments will count towards their participation grade. During peer review, please give constructive criticism using the writing and editing techniques we will learn in this course. In order to receive participation and peer review points for each day, you will need to bring drafts that meet the assignment’s length requirements, to bring the correct number of copies of your draft, to fill out the peer-review sheets, and to stay on-task for the entire review session. 

PARTICIPATION

As your instructor, I am here to facilitate learning, to motivate and support you in your process of coming to terms with the language and culture of the college classroom. Your role as a student is to take responsibility for your learning by participating fully in class activities and discussions, peer groups, conferences, and assignments.

Since this is a discussion-based class, please be particularly attentive to those around you. I want you to feel free to speak up, and I also want our discussions to be productive. Know that thoughtful questions are quite as valuable as other kinds of participation. Use this class as an opportunity to work on your skills at engaging in interesting and productive conversations. You probably don’t think about this fact much, but working at making productive discussion contributions is a way of refining communication skills that will serve you well in interviews, jobs, and social situations.
